Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: barracks room of Avoirdupois Manor

This is the barracks room of the Avoirdupois Manor. It is comprised of four smooth gray stone walls, a hardwood floor, and a simple plastered ceiling. The east and west sides of the area are entirely populated with bunk beds covered in blue linens, which can comfortably accommodate up to two sleepers in each individual unit. Counters have been built along the southern wall and extend into each of the southern corners as surfaces for shared goods. An armor rack stands in the northeast corner, and a weapon rack in the northwest corner, with a thin oak closet door north in the northern walls center. Solid oak doors have been centrally-built into the western wall west, lending access to the front lawn, while the southern door, south, leads to the recreation room of the barracks.
A barracks room of the Avoirdupois Manor.
This is the barracks room of the Avoirdupois Manor. It is comprised of four smooth gray stone walls, a hardwood floor, and a simple plastered ceiling.

the top bunk of the northeastern bunk bed
Supported by sturdy cedar planks is a thin mattress covered with neatly turned pale blue linen sheets, a dark blue wool blanket, and generously fluffed cotton pillow.

northeastern bunk bed

A simple, sturdy cedar bunk bed situated against the east wall. It features both a bottom and top bunk, the latter of which can be accessed via the ladder attached to the upper left-hand side. Each bed has been methodically prepared; the thin mattresses covered with neatly turned pale blue linen sheets, dark blue wool comforters, and generously fluffed cotton pillows.
eastern bunk bed

A simple, sturdy cedar bunk bed situated against the east wall. It features both a bottom and top bunk, the latter of which can be accessed via the ladder attached to the upper left-hand side. Each bed has been methodically prepared; the thin mattresses covered with neatly turned pale blue linen sheets, dark blue wool comforters, and generously fluffed cotton pillows.

the southeastern counter

A simple cedar counter built into the southern wall. Approximately three feet high and five feet long, this counter stretches across the southern wall before bending in the southeast corner as an extended surface for shared goods among the barracks' inhabitants. A solid oak door at the southern wall's center separates this counter from it's opposite mate in the southwest corner.
A simple cedar counter built into the southern wall that extends into the southeast corner.

the eastern wall
The eastern wall of a barracks room. It is comprised entirely of smooth gray stone.
The eastern wall of a barracks room.
the northern wall

The northern wall of a barracks room. It is comprised entirely of smooth gray stone aside from the centermost portion, which breaks to display a solid oak door leading out to the brick-walled courtyard.

the southern wall
